question: Are you affiliated with a bank?

children.label: Yes, I am affiliated with a bank.
children.question: What Went Wrong?

children.label: The AI system permitted a transaction that it should have blocked.
children.question: Who is the complaining party?

children.label: The Bank
children.question: What is the nature of the complaint?

children.label: The Bank's System did not Perform as Advertised by the Vendor.
children.question: What claims does the injury give rise to?

children.label: The Bank's Client
children.question: What is the nature of the complaint?

children.label: Is there any way a bank's client could be injured if the transaction was sent/received as intended?
children.question: What claims does the injury give rise to?

children.label: The Government
children.question: What is the nature of the complaint?

children.label: A Civil Violation.
children.question: What claims does the injury give rise to?

children.label: Anti Terrorism Act
children.question: What is the potential liability?

children.label:
Possible Defense for the Claim under Anti-Terrorism Act
                                                    Lack of the “knowingly” element - The bank is not liable for the injuries caused by AI itself because bank does not satisfy the mental state - “knowingly” element of the liability under Anti-Terrorism Act.  
                                                    Contributory negligence - If AI fails to screen the receiving party is a terrorist because the government does not update the list of terrorists or just negligently fails to notify banks in time, or the programmers forget to update the list or just have not updated it correctly. then the bank would not be liable for the consequence caused by AI.  
                                                    Duty of care – If the bank maintains AI carefully with the information provided by government and has done the best to remain it in the best technology status, then the bank is likely off the hook.    
                                                    Statute of limitations – Statute of Limitation general starts from the damages has occurred. The government might discover the damages when SOL expires, then the bank is likely to use this to defense.
IEEPA & TWEA
children.question: What is the potential liability?

children.label:
Under The International Emergency Economic Powers Act, A civil penalty may be imposed on any person who commits an unlawful act described in subsection (a) in an amount not to exceed the greater of—
                                                $250,000; or
                                                an amount that is twice the amount of the transaction that is the basis of the violation with respect to which the penalty is imposed. 
                                                This violation is very straight forward. Section a explicitly states, it shall be unlawful for a person to violate, attempt to violate... With the violation incurred by the AI, the Bank would be responsible for a civil penalty that would follow.
A Criminal Violation.
children.question: What claims does the injury give rise to?

children.label: Anti Terrorism Act
children.question: What is the potential liability?

children.label:
Anti-Terrorism Act: Civil Actions:
                                            18 U.S. Code § 2339A and 18 U.S. Code § 2339B   
                                            Section 2339A and 2339B creates no private cause of action. However, 18 U.S.C. §2333 authorizes civil lawsuits for those injured in their person, property, or business by an act of international terrorism.          
                                            The courts have concluded that the violations of Section 2339A and 2339B may constitute “acts of international terrorism” for purposes of Section 2333. They do so by construing violations of Section 2339A as acts of “international terrorism” as defined in 18 U.S.C. §2331(1).                                            
                                            Boim v. Quranic Literacy Institute, 291 F.3d 1000, 1015 (7th Cir. 2002) (“If the plaintiffs could show that [the defendants] violated either Section 2339A or 2339B, that conduct would certainly be sufficient to meet the definition of ‘international terrorism’ under Sections 2333 and 2331... Congress has made clear, though, through the criminal liability imposed in Sections 2339A and 2339B, that even small donations made knowingly and intentionally in support of terrorism may meet the standard for civil liability in section 2333”); Goldberg v. UBS AG, 690 F. Supp. 2d 92, 114 (E.D. N.Y. 2010) (“Following the Seventh Circuit’s lead, numerous authorities have similarly interpreted section 2331(1), citing inter alia, Weiss v. National Westminster Bank PLC, 453 F. Supp. 2d 609, 613 (E.D.N.Y. 2006); Almog v. Arab Bank, PLC, 471 F. Supp. 2d 257, 268 (E.D.N.Y. 2007); see also In re Chiquita Brands International, Inc., 690 F. Supp. 2d 1296, 1309 (S.D. Fla. 2010); In re Terrorist Attacks, 392 F. Supp. 2d 539, 564-65(S.D.N.Y. 2005).                        
                                            18 U.S. Code § 2339B:                       
                                            Section 2339B(c) authorizes the Attorney General or the Secretary of the Treasury to bring a civil suit in district court to enjoin violation of the section. 
                                            (2)Financial institutions.—Except as authorized by the Secretary, any financial institution that becomes aware that it has possession of, or control over, any funds in which a foreign terrorist organization, or its agent, has an interest, shall—
                                            (A) retain possession of, or maintain control over, such funds; and
                                            (B) report to the Secretary the existence of such funds in accordance with regulations issued by the Secretary. 
                                            Civil Remedies: 
                                            18 U.S.C. §2333(a): Any national of the United States injured in his or her person, property, or business by reason of an act of international terrorism, or his or her estate, survivors, or heirs, may sue therefor in any appropriate district court of the United States and shall recover threefold the damages he or she sustains and the cost of the suit, including attorney’s fees.
IEEPA & TWEA
children.question: What is the potential liability?

children.label:
Bank’s Defenses for Criminal IEEPA and TWEA
                                            The Government may attempt to prosecute your bank criminally because the AI violated IEEPA or TWEA
                                            The good news is that your bank has a defense 
                                            The criminal statute requires that the crime was committed “willfully”
                                            Since the reason this client was approved was because the AI gave the all clear, it would be difficult to convince any court that the bank did this “willfully.”
                                            The Supreme Court has ruled that: “To establish a 'willful' violation of a statute, the Government must prove that the defendant acted with knowledge that his conduct was unlawful.”
                                            The fact that the bank had an AI in place to prevent this from happening, in and of itself, can help to prove that the act was not committed “willfully.”
